title: "Mario Batali - The Italian Kitchen" simple geometric sans
content:
This is probably one of those that's obvious to everyone ('cept little old me), but could anyone help identify this front for me? At first I thought it was Engraver's Gothic, but closer examination led me to think otherwise. It's slightly jazzier, yes?

Many thanks in advance.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100510011000im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mario_logo_nohome_5512.gif)

author: bhogan

comments.content: Hmmm . . . I looked at lots of Gill variants, and in all the cap "R" and "B" look quite a bit different.

Check out some of Gill Sans' descendants, like Bliss or Today Sans.

[http://www.typography.net/type/bliss.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20100510011000/http:/www.typography.net/type/bliss.htm "http://www.typography.net/type/bliss.htm")  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/today-sans/](http://web.archive.org/web/20100510011000/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/today-sans/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/today-sans/")

Gotham isn't too far off, either.

[http://typography.com/catalog/gotham/more09.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20100510011000/http:/typography.com/catalog/gotham/more09.html "http://typography.com/catalog/gotham/more09.html")

Gotham is close, I think, but there are still differences in the "R" and "B"--which leads me to believe that it's another typeface. But thanks for pointing me to Gotham, which I like in its own right.

Y'all are so great, wow. This is the closest yet, but I don't think an exact match. The "T" in the Mario specimens is wider, as I see it, and the ampersand quite a bit taller. But thanks for pointing me to this font.
Sorry, my fault. There's some more of the type at [www.italiankitchen.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20100510011000/http:/www.italiankitchen.com/ "www.italiankitchen.com").

Granby is close too but the R doesn't match.

[http://www.identifont.com/find?font=granby&q=Go](http://web.archive.org/web/20100510011000/http:/www.identifont.com/find?font=granby&q=Go "http://www.identifont.com/find?font=granby&q=Go")

I think it's P22 London Underground.

Perhaps [ITC Johnston](http://web.archive.org/web/20100510011000/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&startrow=1&records=&currpage=1&totalrecords=15&displayfontid=C.118887.0.0&fontRendererText=MARIO+BATALI+G) then, as the 'R' in [P22 Johnston Underground](http://web.archive.org/web/20100510011000/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=PY.114314.0.2&attributes.sampleSize=24&sampleText=MARIO+BATALI+G&sampleSize=32) is more exaggerated.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100510011000im_/http:/typophile.com/files/get_Font_Image_6150.php.png)
  
ITC Johnston by Dave Farey

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100510011000im_/http:/typophile.com/files/get_Font_Image-1_4709.php.png)
  
P22 Johnston Underground by Richard Kegler

Both fonts have some kerning issues on the ATA, btw. P22s is more noticeable but consistent.
